climbs.name: Warning
climbs.fa: Mike Lewis, Rusty Lewis, Mike Johnson July 1988

content.description:
This is a fun route that is a slightly harder version of the Lewis bros 'Rockwalk' on Runner Rock.  

  Climb the featured slab past 2 bolts to the base of the bulge and crack. Pull the short, but burly crux protected by a bolt and dive into the crack. Pass another bolt through the wide stem flare and another on the upper face after the crack.  

  Once you reach the 2nd bolt this climb is never run-out. Although the climbing is not hard, you do break into ground fall territory getting to this bolt.
content.protection: Micro - BD#3, nuts   5 bolts   2 bolt anchor
content.location: West face of Stonehenge, starts on the featured slab behind a tree right off the trail.   Walk off or rap 'Sing Me Spanish Techno' w/ a 70m

climbs.name: The Phoenix
climbs.fa: FTR  Kevin Bein 6/30/87  FFA  Chris Hirsch 5/5/2014

content.description:
Piana once called this line more beautiful than the Salathe Headwall! It certainly has caught many climbers' attention. Kevin Bein top roped the line in '87 calling it 'So You Wanna Layback?'. Since then few others have attempted on TR and it was more commonly called 'The Phoenix'. 

  Begin on a hollow, right-facing flake. As the flake dies out, transition right up thin face to a large jug rail at the base of overhang. Clip bolt and run it out through the first hard section before the seam allows gear. Continue the sustained liebacking to a decent rest at mid-height. The crux above is desperate and sparsely protected. A .5/.75 or red/black Metolius offset cam is comforting. Switch between right and left liebacking a couple times through the pumpy, S-ing finish. 

  Due to the nature of the rock (not the cleanest in the park), and therefore questionable gear, difficulty, and cowardice, I resorted to Headpoint style. Though the one and only bolt was placed on lead. Hopefully future ascents will better this style.
content.protection: Single rack; red C3-#2, doubles of .4 and .5, nuts   1 bolt   2 bolt anchor with chain
content.location: This is the seam on the overhanging, streaked, SE wall. First seen when coming through the tunnel from the lake. Single 70m rope rap.

content.description: The route starts up the slightly leftward trending water groove (described in the description for the area) and is protected by bolts. Move onto the first block past two bolts (crux) then onto a ledge with another bolt. Move onto summit block and climb the airy finish to the top.
content.protection: Five Protection Bolts plus a flake or two can be runnered; Summit has bolted anchors.
content.location: (described in detail in the description for the area)

climbs.name: How's it Hanging?
climbs.fa: Chris Hirsch, Tony Schwartz, Randy Baum, June 2017 (ground-up)

content.description: Sharing the first two and last bolts of Warning, this climb hangs slightly right. Extend the first two bolts, make a long reach and pull the steep arete. Crux is well protected and falls are completely clean. Continue up flared crack that splits the arete while placing gear. One more bolt protects the exit to the slab.
content.protection: 6 bolts   Cams red C3 - .75 & nuts   Chain anchors
content.location: Right off the Sunday gulch trail (to the N) behind big spruce. 60m rope gets you down.

content.description:
Climb the wide crack with difficulty. Where it ends move up and right on thin crystals to a bolt. Continue up to a second bolt and make a few thin (5.9 ?) moves to easier ground. 

  This was led ground-up and onsight. I spent a long time trying to avoid placing the second bolt, using RPs for pro instead, climbing up and down, but finally opted to drill and promptly broke the drill bit. Kevin tied me off to the railing and ran back to the car, returning a while later with another bit.
content.protection: Wide stuff for the crack. Two bolts for the face.
content.location: The overhanging wide crack just off the trail on the left, about 150 feet downhill from the dam.

content.description:
The summit of Stonehenge consists of two blocks leaning together forming a corridor thru the formation. An airy summit perched atop an elevated plain and is composed of excellent rock. This area can be crowded due the top rope routes nearby that are popular with climbing schools and beginners. Fortunately Stonehenge forms a fifth class summit with little or no protection on the easiest route. 

  Herb & Jan Conn climbed the first ascent of this pinnacle in 1960 via a wide spread and an airy traverse but didn't remember any other details.
